Legal_Issue: Do the applicants qualify as Convention refugees or persons in need of protection under sections 96 and 97 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act?
Application_Facts: Applicants claimed refugee status in Canada, citing fear of persecution in Zimbabwe due to perceived political opinions.
The wife and child relied solely on the principal applicant's claim without independent evidence.
Remedy_Requested: Judicial review of the Refugee Protection Division's decision
Court_Ruling: Federal Court dismissed the application, finding no reviewable errors in the Board's decision.
Grounds_for_Claim: Fear of persecution due to perceived political opinions in Zimbabwe
Legal_Standard: Well-founded fear of persecution for a Convention reason
Applicable_Legislation: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, sections 96 and 97
Credibility_Assessment: No credible evidence of persecution found
Evidence_Used: Reliance on principal applicantâ€™s claim by family members
Legal_Provision_Cited: Sections 96 and 97 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Governing_Rule: Applicants must demonstrate a well-founded fear of persecution for a Convention reason
Evidentiary_Deficiency: No independent evidence from wife and child
Insufficient proof of political activity or persecution
Harm_Assessment: Alleged risk of persecution in Zimbabwe based on political opinion
Cause_Description: Applicants claimed refugee status in Canada, citing fear of persecution in Zimbabwe due to perceived political opinions.
Evidence_Handling: Board assessed credibility and sufficiency of evidence; found claim unsubstantiated
Evidence_Issues: Dependence on principal applicant's unverified claims
Legal_Provision: Section 96 (Convention refugee), Section 97 (person in need of protection)
Evidence_Assessment: Findings of 'asylum shopping' and unrestricted travel undermined credibility
Decision_Rationale: No credible basis for fear of persecution; no reviewable error identified
